"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Case 6:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"   When "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+b=15"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ordered pairs; "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(a,b)=(6,9),(9,6),(7,8),(8,7)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The divisibility rule for 3 tells us that "A number is divisible by 3 if, and only if, its digits sum is divisible by 3"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This means that we want "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1+a+b+2\equiv 0\pmod 3\Leftrightarrow a+b\equiv 0\pmod 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This is only possible if"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a\equiv b\equiv 0\pmod 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(a,b)\equiv (1,2)\pmod 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(a,b)\equiv (2,1)\pmod 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The first case is possible when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a,b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are congruent to one of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\{0,3,6,9\}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which is possible in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4^2=16"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ways."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The last 2 cases are possible when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a,b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are congruent to one of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1,4,7"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2,5,8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in some order, for a total of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2\cdot 3^2=18"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ways."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So the total number of ways is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"16+18=\boxed{34}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Solution:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
34 Ordered Pairs"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Key aspect of the solution:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For the number 1ab2 to be multiple of 3, the sum of the digits 1 + a + b + 2 must be divisible by 3. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We already have:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"With the two extreme digits summing to 3, we are left with finding all the ordered pairs (a,b) that are multiples of 3. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"It is sufficient to find the ordered pairs as per the condition below to form the full set of solutions:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The set of numbers that fit the ordered pair (a,b) being multiple of 3 is {0, 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18}."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Elaboration of ordered pairs for each element of the solution set:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 ordered pair for element "0";  (0,0) is the only ordered pair that satisfies this element."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4 ordered pairs for element "3"; (0,3), (1,2), (2,1), (3,0) are the ordered pairs for this element."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"7 ordered pairs for element "6"; (0,6), (1,5), (2,4), (3,3), (4,2), (5,1), (6,0)  are the ordered pairs for this element."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10 ordered pairs for element "9"; (0,9), (1,8), (2,7), ..., (8,1), (9,0)  are the ordered pairs for this element."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"7 ordered pairs for element "12"; (3,9), (4,8), ..., (8,4), (9,3)  are the ordered pairs for this element."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4 ordered pairs for element "15"; (6,9), (7,8), (8,7), (9,6)  are the ordered pairs for this element."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 ordered pair for the element "18"; (9,9) is the only ordered pair that satisfies this element."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We can proceed with casework on the sum of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", as the sum of the digits of any number divisible by 3 is divisible by 3. Thus, the sum "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can equal 0, 3,6,9,12,15, or 18. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"*if a+b=0 *","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"Then there is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are legal ordered pair"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"if a+b=3","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"  Then there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are legal ordered pairs"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"*if a+b=6 *","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"Then there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 7 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are legal ordered pairs"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"*if a+b=9 *","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"Then there are"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 10 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are legal ordered pairs"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"*if a+b=12 *","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"Then there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 7 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are legal ordered pairs"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"*if a+b=15 *","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"Then there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are legal ordered pairs"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"*if a+b=18 *","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"Then there is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are legal ordered pair"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The total is thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1+4+7+10+7+4+1= \boxed{34} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" legal ordered pairs"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since 1 and 2 already add up to 3, the sum of a and b must be a multiple of 3. Here are the possibilities:
3: 12, 21, 03, 30"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6: 33, 42, 24, 15, 51, 06, 60"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9: 18, 81, 72, 27, 63, 36, 09, 90, 45, 54 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"15: 96, 69, 78, 87 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"18: 99"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0: 00 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"That is 34 of them in all. I know there would be an easier way."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{n}{m^{n+1}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can be written as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{n}{m^{n}}}{m}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{n+1}{m^{n+1}}}{m}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", as the first term is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"It can further be written as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{n}{m^{n}}}{m^{2}} + \frac{\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{1}{m^{n}}}{m^{2}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Simplifying, we get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{n}{m^{n}}}{m} = \frac{1}{(m-1)^{2}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", whose summation from 2 to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\infty"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{\pi^{2}}{6}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The only way you can end up with nine blue chameleons are if there are 3 groups with one green and two blues each, and one group with three green ones in it."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The total number of ways to split the twelve chameleons into four groups of three is:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" N = \frac{12!}{(3!)^4\times4!} = 15400"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The 12! on the top is the total number of ways to pick the 12 chameleons.  The 4! accounts for the number of ways you can rearrange the 4 groups.  And the four 3!'s account for the different ways each of the four groups could have been arranged."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"And the number that have the combinations described above is given by:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n = \frac{3\binom{6}{3}\times2\binom{6}{2}\times\binom{4}{2}}{3!} = 1800"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This is because there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\binom{6}{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ways to pick 3 green ones in one group, then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\binom{6}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ways to choose the one green and two blues in the next group, and finally "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\binom{4}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ways of picking one green and two blues in the third group.  The fourth group is just the left overs so only one choice there once the other three groups are chosen."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So the probability we will end up with a combination that will give us nine blue chameleons is given by:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P = n/N = 1800/15400 = 9/77"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9+77 = \boxed{86}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Name the blue chameleons "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B_1, B_2, B_3, \ldots, B_6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and the green chameleons "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"G_1, G_2, G_3, \ldots, G_6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"First, to have 9 blue chameleons, it means we need to convert three green ones to blue. However, to convert a chameleon to a color, we need two of that color and one of another color in a group. Thus, to convert a green chameleon to blue, we need two blue chameleons to convert it. Since we need to convert three green chameleons to blue, we need six blue chameleons to convert them all, exactly enough. So there are three groups where green chameleons get converted to blue ones, and the remaining one is all green."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Consider the group containing "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B_1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". It must contain one other blue chameleon and one green chameleon. Choosing the blue chameleon has "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{5}{11}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" probability, then choosing the green chameleon has "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{6}{10}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" probability (after choosing that blue one, we have 6 out of 10 that are green); we multiply by 2 because we could have picked them in either order (blue first then green, or the other way around)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"WLOG it's not "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B_2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" that's chosen (otherwise rename chameleons). Consider the group containing "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B_2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Again, we need one blue chameleon, with probability "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{3}{8}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (3 out of 8 chameleons remaining are blue), and one green with probability "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{5}{7}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and again we multiply by 2."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Likewise with the third group. We fix one blue chameleon "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B_3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"; there's "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{1}{5}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" probability to get another blue, followed by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{4}{4}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" probability to get a green; we multiply by 2 again. The remaining three green chameleons automatically form the last group."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In total, that's "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{5}{11} \cdot \frac{6}{10} \cdot 2 \cdot \frac{3}{8} \cdot \frac{5}{7} \cdot 2 \cdot \frac{1}{5} \cdot \frac{4}{4} \cdot 2 = \frac{9}{77}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" chance of getting the picks right."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Struggled with this one.. used a longer approach... the solutions by Geoff and Ivan are unquestionably the way to go... still...for what its worth... posting the way I solved... "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"There are 5 basic sets that can be formed "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1) 3B, 3B, 3G, 3G"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3B, 3G each can be arranged in 1 way and the 4 groups can be arranged in 4!/2!2! = 6 ways so total of 6 ways "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2) 2B1G, 2B1G, 2B1G, 3G "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2B1G each can be arranged in 3!/2! = 3 ways so 27 ways and the 4 groups can be arranged in 4!/3!= 4 ways so total of 108 ways"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3) 2G1B, 2G1B, 2G1B, 3B"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2G1B each can be arranged in 3!/2! = 3 ways so 27 ways and the 4 groups can be arranged in 4!/3!= 4 ways so total of 108 ways"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4) 2B1G, 2B1G, 2G1B, 2G1B"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2B1G AND 2G1B each arranged in 3!/2! = 3 ways so 81 ways and the 4 groups in 4!/2!2! = 6ways so total of 486 ways "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5) 3B, 3G, 2B1G, 2G1B "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2G1B, 2B1G each arranged in 3 ways and 3B, 3G each in 1 way so 9 ways and the 4 groups arranged in 4! = 24 ways so total of 216 ways "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Total number of ways = 6 + 108 + 108 + 486 + 216 = 924 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The only way to form 9 Blue and 3 Green is set number 2 to wit 2B1G, 2B1G, 2B1G, 3G in 108 ways  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Probability = 108/924 = 9/77 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Great problem Geoff!"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

Multiplying this we get the number of ways to split the blue chameleons into 3 groups consisting of two fellows, but the order is preserved so we divide by 3!. Then, there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{6}\choose{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ways to choose the companions for our pairs of blue chameleons, and there are 3! ways to combine green singles and blue pairs. Finally, we should divide this by the total number of ways to split chameleons into 4 groups by 3, which can be written as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{\binom{12}{3} \times \binom{9}{3} \times \binom{6}{3}}{4!}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \frac{\frac{\binom{6}{2}\times\binom{4}{2}}{3!}\times\binom{6}{3}\times3!}{\frac{\binom{12}{3} \times \binom{9}{3} \times \binom{6}{3}}{4!}} = \frac{9}{77}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let each blue and each green chameleon be represented by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B,\:G"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", respectively and name the four chameleon groups "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"G_1,\:\ldots,\:G_4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
\underset{G_1}{\underbrace{p_1,\:p_2,\:p_3}},   \:\ldots,\:   \underset{G_4}{\underbrace{p_{10},\:p_{11},\:p_{12}}}
"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"When the chameleons form groups randomly, it is the same as if they each choose one of the 12 positions randomly - if we align these positions as above, that is equivalent to forming a 12-letter word consisting of six letters "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B,\:G"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" each. The total number of different groups the chameleons can form is equal to the number of possibilities to choose 6 of 12 positions for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", that is
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\binom{12}{6}=914"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"To end up with nine blue chameleons, we need to convert three chameleons from green to blue. That is only possible with three groups "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"BBG"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (in any other order) and one group "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"GGG"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Now let's count the number of words that satisfy these conditions:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We have four choices in which "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"G_i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to place "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"GGG"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Each of the other three groups consists of either "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"BBG,\:BGB"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"GBB"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" - remember we consider the positions to be distinct!"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The probability to end up with nine blue chameleons and three green ones is
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
P=\frac{4\cdot 3^3}{914}=\frac{9}{77}\quad\Rightarrow\quad a+b=9+77=\boxed{86}
"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
